p: Aquilaria agallocha Roxb. (Thymelaeaceae), commonly known as “agarwood”, grows wild in the Himalayan region and East India, and it is cultivated in India, Bangladesh, Indonesia, and Sri Lanka [ 25]. Agarwood EOs and extracts contain a complex mixture of sesquiterpenes and chromones. Depending on the extraction technique, fatty acids and phenols have also been identified. A number of biological properties have been reported for this species, such as antioxidant, antimicrobial, antidiabetic, and antinociceptive properties [ 26, 27].
